entry.title: Java8 å‡½æ•°å¼è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­çš„å¼‚å¸¸å¤„ç†
entry.content:
1. Overview(æ¦‚è¦)

In Java 8, Lambda Expressions started to facilitate functional programming by providing a concise way to express behavior. However, the Functional Interfaces provided by the JDK donâ€™t deal with exceptions very well â€“ and the code becomes verbose and cumbersome when it comes to handling them.

In this article, weâ€™ll explore some ways to deal with exceptions when writing lambda expressions.

2. Handling Unchecked Exceptionsï¼ˆå¤„ç†ä¸å¯æ£€å¼‚å¸¸ï¼‰

First, letâ€™s understand the problem with an example.

We have a List<Integer> and we want to divide a constant, say 50 with every element of this list and print the results:

This expression works but thereâ€™s one problem. If any of the elements in the list is 0, then we get an ArithmeticException: / by zero. Letâ€™s fix that by using a traditional try-catch block such that we log any such exception and continue execution for next elements:

The use of try-catch solves the problem, but the conciseness of a Lambda Expression is lost and itâ€™s no longer a small function as itâ€™s supposed to be.

To deal with this problem, we can write a lambda wrapper for the lambda function. Letâ€™s look at the code to see how it works:

At first, we wrote a wrapper method that will be responsible for handling the exception and then passed the lambda expression as a parameter to this method.

The wrapper method works as expected but, you may argue that itâ€™s basically removing the try-catch block from lambda expression and moving it to another method and it doesnâ€™t reduce the actual number of lines of code being written.

This is true in this case where the wrapper is specific to a particular use case but we can make use of generics to improve this method and use it for a variety of other scenarios:

As we can see, this iteration of our wrapper method takes two arguments, the lambda expression and the type of Exception to be caught. This lambda wrapper is capable of handling all data types, not just Integers, and catch any specific type of exception and not the superclass Exception.

Also, notice that we have changed the name of the method from lambdaWrapper to consumerWrapper. Itâ€™s because this method only handles lambda expressions for Functional Interface of type Consumer. We can write similar wrapper methods for other Functional Interfaces like Function, BiFunction, BiConsumer and so on.

3. Handling Checked Exceptionsï¼ˆå¤„ç†å¯æ£€å¼‚å¸¸ï¼‰

Letâ€™s consider the example from the previous section, but instead of dividing and printing the integers to the console, we want to write them to a file. This operation of writing to a file throws IOException.

On compilation, we get the following error.

Since IOException is a checked exception, it must be handled. Now there are two options, we may want to throw the exception and handle it somewhere else or handle it inside the method that has the lambda expression. Letâ€™s look at each of them one by one.

3.1. Throwing Checked Exception from Lambda Expressionsï¼ˆä»å‡½æ•°å¼è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­æŠ›å‡ºå¯æ£€å¼‚å¸¸ï¼‰

Letâ€™s throw the exception from the method in which the lambda expression is written, in this case, the main:

Still, while compiling, we get the same error of unhandled IOException. This is because lambda expressions are similar to Anonymous Inner Classes. In this case, the lambda expression is an implementation of accept(T t) method from Consumer interface.

Throwing the exception from main is does nothing and since the method in the parent interface doesnâ€™t throw any exception, it canâ€™t in its implementation:

The above code doesnâ€™t compile because the implementation of accept method canâ€™t throw any Exception.

The most straightforward way would be to use a try-catch and wrap the checked exception into an unchecked exception and rethrow:

This approach gets the code to compile and run but has the same problem as the example in the case of unchecked exceptions in the previous section.

Since we just want to throw the exception, we need to write our own Consumer Functional Interface which can throw an exception and then a wrapper method using it. Letâ€™s call it ThrowingConsumer:

Now we can write our lambda expression which can throw exceptions without losing the conciseness.

3.2. Handling a Checked Exception in Lambda Expressionï¼ˆåœ¨å‡½æ•°å¼è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­å¤„ç†å¯æ£€å¼‚å¸¸ï¼‰

In this final section. we will modify the wrapper to handle checked exceptions. Since our ThrowingConsumer interface uses generics, we can handle any specific exception.

We can user this wrapper in our example to handle only the IOException and throw any other checked exception by wrapping them in an unchecked exception:

Similar to the case of unchecked exceptions, throwing siblings for other Functional Interfaces like ThowingFunction, ThrowingBiFunction, ThrowingBiConsumer etc. can be written along with their corresponding wrapper methods.

4. Conclusionï¼ˆæ€»ç»“ï¼‰

In this article, we covered how to handle a specific exception in lambda expressions without losing the conciseness by use of wrapper methods. We also learned how to write throwing alternatives for the Functional Interfaces present in JDK to either throw a checked exception by wrapping them in an unchecked exception or to handle them.
